questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to the passage of blood in her urine, along with complaints of left flank pain, fatigue and generalised weakness. She has a history of recurrent renal stones. USG confirmed the presence of renal stones in her left renal pelvis. Lab reports show the following values. Based on the values given below, what is the most likely diagnosis?


 


	Blood pH - 7.29
	Serum sodium - 144 mEq/L
	Serum potassium - 3.1 mEq/L
	Serum bicarbonate - 9 mEq/L
	Urine pH - 5.8
	Urine calcium - elevated
	Urine citrate - low
	Normal anion gap
questions.solution:
As this patient has non-anion gap acidosis, hypokalemia, hypocitraturia and hypercalciuria with renal stones, it is most likely due to Type 1 Renal tubular acidosis.

Type 1 renal tubular acidosis  
Defect
  • Inability of the alpha intercalated cells (DCT) to secrete H+ into urine ➜ Metabolic acidosis
  • ￬ H+ excretion leads to ￬ K+ reabsorption ➜ Hypokalemia
Serum electrolytes Hypokalemia
Urine changes Hypocitraturia, hypercalciuria, pH> 5.5
Causes
  • Amphotericin B
  • Analgesic toxicity
  • Lithium toxicity
  • Autoimmunity (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Sjogren's syndrome)
  • Hyperglobulinemia
Association
  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Osteopenia / osteomalacia / Rickets
Management
  • Oral sodium bicarbonate ➜ Neutralizes acidosis
  • Treating hypokalemia (potassium citrate)

Type 2 Renal tubular acidosis (Option A) is associated with glycosuria, aminoaciduria, phosphaturia, and hypokalemia. Urine pH depends on the serum bicarbonate level; when serum bicarbonate is low, urine pH is less than 5.5, and vice versa.

 

Hyperparathyroidism (Option B) can cause hypercalcemia, which leads to hypercalciuria and renal stones, but metabolic acidosis is not a feature of hyperparathyroidism. It usually presents with features of hypercalcemia, such as renal stones, osteoporosis, abdominal pain and confusion/irritability (Stones, Bones, Groans and psychiatric overtones)

 

Hypoaldosteronism (Option C) causes hyperkalemia and less NH4+ secretion in the urine, thus causing mild metabolic acidosis. It is typically associated with urine pH< 5.5, and there is no association with renal stones.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the OPD for a regular annual check-up. Her blood tests reveal a serum bicarbonate level of 12 mEq/L, serum potassium of 3.2 mEq/L, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. Urine pH is 5.2, and aminoaciduria and glycosuria are detected despite normal blood glucose levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis is Proximal Renal Tubular Acidosis (Type 2 RTA) with Fanconi syndrome.
  • Proximal RTA occurs due to defective bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, leading to a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis and low serum bicarbonate.
  • Despite the acidosis, the kidneys can still acidify the urine, resulting in a urine pH below 5.5.
  • Hypokalemia (serum potassium of 3.2 mEq/L) is also a feature of proximal RTA.
Type 2 Renal tubular acidosis  
Defect

Defective HCO3- reabsorption in the PCT ➜ Metabolic acidosis
Serum electrolytes

Hypokalemia

Due to ￪ HCO3⁻ loss ➜ Higher sodium delivery to the distal tubule ➜ Increased potassium excretion ➜ Hypokalemia
Urine changes Glycosuria, aminoaciduria, phosphaturia (Fanconi syndrome) pH< 5.5
Causes
  • Fanconi syndrome
  • Wilson's disease
  • Multiple myeloma (Paraproteinaemia)
  • Heavy metals (Lead, cadmium, mercury)
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
  • Tenofovir, topiramate
  • Expired tetracycline
  • Galactosemia
  • Cystinosis
  • Cisplatin therapy
Association Hypophosphatemic rickets in Fanconi syndrome
Treatment

Oral sodium bicarbonate

Thiazide diuretics

Distal Renal tubular acidosis (Option A) is type 1 RTA, which occurs due to the inability of alpha intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) to secrete H+, leading to urine pH >5.5 despite metabolic acidosis. It is characterised by hypokalemia, hypocitraturia, and hypercalciuria and is associated with osteomalacia/rickets, nephrolithiasis, and nephrocalcinosis.

 

Generalised Renal tubular acidosis (Option B) is type 4 RTA and is characterised by hyperkalemia due to aldosterone deficiency or resistance. Urinary ammonium excretion is depressed; thus, there is mild metabolic acidosis, and the urine pH is typically <5.5.

 

Bartter syndrome (Option C) is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting Na+/K+/Cl- in the thick ascending loop of Henle. It is characterised by metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, and hypercalciuria.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes presents with generalised weakness, muscle cramps, and fatigue for the past 3 weeks. He has hypertension and chronic kidney disease and is currently taking metformin, spironolactone, and furosemide. If diagnosed with Type 4 renal tubular acidosis, which finding would be least likely in his investigation report?
questions.solution:
Hypokalemia is least likely in Type 4 RTA, as this condition typically presents with hyperkalemia, distinguishing it from other forms of RTA (Type 1 and 2) where hypokalemia is common.

 

Type 4 renal tubular acidosis

Defect

Hypoaldosteronism or aldosterone resistance (Option A)

Serum electrolytes

Hyperkalemia (Option B ruled out)

Urine changes

Low ammonium (Option C), pH< 5.5, normal urinary calcium (Option D)

Causes

  • Hypoaldosteronism
    • Diabetic hypo-reninism
    • HIV associated nephropathy
    • ACE inhibitors / ARB
    • Cyclosporine, NSAIDs
    • Adrenal insufficiency
  • Aldosterone resistance
    • K+ sparing diuretics
    • Obstructive nephropathy
    • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX)
  • Renal transplant rejection

Treatment

Furosemide (for hyperkalemia)

Dietary potassium restriction

Mineralocorticoid replacement: Fludrocortisone

questions.text:
Match the following types of renal tubular acidosis (RTA) with their mechanism of action,

 


	
		
			
			
				RTA type 1
			
			
			
			a. Epithelial sodium channels resistance to aldosterone
			
		
		
			
			2. RTA type 2
			
			
			b. Damage to alpha intercalated cells
			
		
		
			
			3. RTA type 4
			
			
			c. Generalized dysfunctioning of proximal convoluted tubule
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

Explanation:

  • Types of RTA (Renal Tubular Acidosis)

 

 

RTA type 1

RTA type 2

RTA type 4

Site

DCT (distal convoluted tubule)

PCT (proximal convoluted tubule)

DCT (distal convoluted tubule)

Mechanism

Damage to alpha intercalated cells

Generalized dysfunctioning of proximal convoluted tubule

Epithelial sodium channels resistance to aldosterone

Serum potassium levels

Low

Low

High

questions.text: Which of the following statements about renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is incorrect?

choices.text: Hydrogen ion retention occurs in Type 1 RTA
Excess bicarbonate loss occurs in Type 2 RTA
Hyperkalemia is a characteristic feature of Type 4 RTA
Increased urinary ammonium excretion is seen in Type 4 RTA

questions.solution:
RTA 4 is not associated with ammonium loss, rather, ammonium retention occurs, which leads to mild metabolic acidosis.

 

Renal tubular acidosis type

Potassium

Bicarbonate

Hydrogen ion

Ammonium

Chloride

Type 1

↓

Normal

↑ (retained)

Normal

↑

Type 2

↓

↓ (lost in urine)

Normal

Normal

↑

Type 4

↑

Normal

Normal

↑ (retained)

↑



 

 

RTA type 1

RTA type 2

RTA type 4

Pathology

Inability of the alpha intercalated cells (DCT) to secrete H+ into the urine

Defective HCO3- reabsorption in the PCT

Hypoaldosteronism or aldosterone resistance

Serum electrolytes

Hypokalemia

Hypokalemia

Hyperkalemia

Urine changes

Hypocitraturia, hypercalciuria

pH> 5.5

Glycosuria, aminoaciduria, phosphaturia

pH< 5.5

Low ammonium

pH< 5.5

Causes

  • Amphotericin B Analgesic toxicity
  • Lithium toxicity Autoimmunity - SLE, Sjogrens
  • Hyperglobulinemia
  • Fanconi syndrome
  • Wilson's disease
  • Multiple myeloma - paraproteinaemia
  • Heavy metals - lead, cadmium, mercury
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor
  • Tenofovir, topiramate
  • Expired tetracycline
  • Hypoaldosteronism
    • Diabetic hypo-reninism
    • HIV associated nephropathy
    • ACE inhibitors / ARB
    • Cyclosporine, NSAIDs
    • Adrenal insufficiency
  • Aldosterone resistance
    • K+ sparing diuretics
    • Obstructive nephropathy
    • TMP-SMX
  • Renal transplant rejection

Associations

  • Nephrolithiasis
  • Nephrocalcinosis
  • osteomalacia / rickets

Hypophosphatemic rickets in Fanconi syndrome

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her family due to 2 days of persistent vomiting, nausea, confusion, and deep, rapid breathing. Her family reports that she has been lethargic and disoriented, with increasing difficulty responding to questions. She has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Based on the lab findings given below, identify the type of metabolic disorder.


 


	Blood pH - 7.28
	Sodium - 140 mEq/L
	Potassium - 5.4 mEq/L
	Bicarbonate - 10 mEq/L


 


	Chloride - 98 mEq/l
	pCO2 - 22 mm hg
	pO2 - 95 mmHg
	RBS - 382 mg/dL
questions.solution:
Option A) High anion gap metabolic acidosis

Based on the clinical features, medical history and investigation values given, this patient has high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) due to Diabetic ketoacidosis.

  • Normal blood pH: 7.37-7.42
  • Anion gap (AG) = [Na⁺] - ([Cl⁻] + [HCO₃⁻])
  • Normal AG = 8-12 mEq/L

 

From the given scenario

  • Blood pH= 7.28, which is lower than the normal range: Acidosis
  • Bicarbonate= 10 mEq/L and pCO2= 22 mmHg: Metabolic
  • Anion gap = [Na⁺] - ([Cl⁻] + [HCO₃⁻])
    • AG=140 - (98+10) = 32, which is higher than the normal range: High anion Gap

 

Metabolic acidosis

High anion gap

Non-anion gap

  • Methanol poisoning
  • Uremia: AKI, CKD
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Paracetamol poisoning
  • Iron and isoniazid
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Ethylene glycol poisoning
  • Salicylate poisoning
  • Hyperchloremia
  • Addison's disease
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Diarrhoea and conditions causing GI loss of HCO3- (ureterosigmoidostomy or external bowel drainage)
  • Acetazolamide
  • Spironolactone and K-sparing diuretics
  • Saline infusion (rapid infusion )

Reduced anion gap: Multiple myeloma and nephrotic syndrome

 

Respiratory acidosis (Option C) occurs when pCO2 is elevated (above 45 mm hg). In this patient, the pCO2 is low, which rather indicates compensatory hyperventilation for the metabolic acidosis leading to CO2 washout.

 

Metabolic alkalosis (Option D) is characterised by elevated HCO3 and increased blood pH. Moreover, rather than hyperventilating, respiratory compensation occurs by reducing the respiratory rate to retain CO2.

questions.text:
Clinical question

A 32-year-old woman presents with fatigue, muscle weakness, recurrent kidney stones, a history of recurrent UTIs, occasional nausea, vomiting, tingling in her hands and feet, and bone pain. Laboratory results show serum bicarbonate = 15 mEq/L, serum potassium = 1.9 mEq/L, and urine pH = 6. Which of the following is true regarding the anion gap in this condition?

choices.text: High in both plasma and urine
High in plasma, normal in urine
Normal in plasma, high in urine
Normal in both plasma and urine

questions.solution:
This scenario of recurrent kidney stones, UTIs, nausea, vomiting, tingling, and bone pain, along with low serum bicarbonate and potassium, is most likely indicative of renal tubular acidosis (RTA), in which the urine anion gap is elevated while the plasma anion gap stays normal.

 

  • Anion gap (AG) = [Na⁺] - ([Cl⁻] + [HCO₃⁻])
  • Normal AG = 8-12 mEq/L
  • Normal plasma anion gap metabolic acidosis can be seen in,

 

Anion gap

RTA

Diarrhea

Plasma

Normal

Normal

Urine

Positive

Negative

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of resistant hypertension, with blood pressure readings consistently around 170/110 mmHg despite treatment. O/E, the physician notes a bruit over the right flank. Renal imaging shows the finding, as given in the image. What is the most common cause of the condition in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of an elderly patient presenting with resistant hypertension along with bruit over the flank and imaging showing an asymmetric shrunk kidney suggests Renal Artery Stenosis (RAS).
  • Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of renal artery stenosis in older patients, especially those with resistant hypertension and vascular disease, indicated by the presence of a bruit.

 

Renal Artery Stenosis: (Narrowing of the renal arteries)

  • The green arrow points towards RAS & shrunk kidney can be seen. (Asymmetric)
  • Aetiology:
    • Atherosclerosis: Most common cause in older adults & usually affects the ostium of the renal artery
    • Fibromuscular Dysplasia (Option A): More common in younger patients (ages 15-30), characterised by irregular narrowing (beading) in the distal renal artery and intrarenal branches.
    • Takayasu Arteritis (Option C): More common in young indians
    • Rare Causes: Include vasculitis, thromboembolism (Option D) & aneurysms.
  • Pathophysiology:

  • Renal Artery Stenosis" data-author="" data-hash="8433" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="" height="544" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/pql0VGVBurwywtBZhwKb1744280141.png" width="710" />

  • Significant renal blood flow reduction occurs with over 70% artery narrowing.
  • Severe stenosis can lead to global renal ischemia, kidney shrinkage, and renal failure, especially if bilateral or if a single solitary kidney is affected.

 

  • Clinical Features:
    • Severe, recent-onset, or difficult-to-control hypertension
    • Asymmetrical kidney sizes
    • Recurrent flash pulmonary oedema (especially with bilateral disease)
    • Peripheral vascular disease in the lower limbs
    • Renal impairment
    • Presence of Abdominal bruit.
    • Deterioration in renal function following initiation of ACE-Inb/ARBs. (efferent arteriolar dilatation), therefore, contraindicated.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with resistant high blood pressure despite multiple antihypertensive medications. Imaging studies show an asymmetric shrunken kidney on the left side. Which of the following diagnostic methods is considered the gold standard for confirming the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
• he clinical presentation suggests renal artery stenosis (RAS).
  • Intraarterial angiography is the gold standard for confirming RAS, as it allows for direct visualisation of the renal arteries, enabling precise assessment of the severity and location of any stenosis.

 

Investigations for Renal Artery Stenosis:

  • Doppler Ultrasound:
    • Measures blood flow velocities in the renal arteries to evaluate for stenosis.
    • Non-invasive and provides real-time assessment of hemodynamics.
  • Duplex Ultrasonography:
    • Assesses renal artery flow and detects stenosis.
    • Inexpensive, widely available, and suitable for follow-up.
    • Less effective for diagnosing fibromuscular dysplasia
  • Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA): (Option B)
    • Visualises renal arteries & perirenal aorta & non-nephrotoxic
    • Expensive & not suitable for patients with GFR <30 mL/min due to gadolinium toxicity & cannot visualise stented vessels.
  • Computed Tomographic Angiography (CTA): (Option C)
    • Offers detailed images of renal arteries and surrounding structures.
    • Excellent visualisation; stents do not cause artifacts & require contrast
  • Intraarterial Angiography: (Gold standard)
    • Directly visualises renal arteries to assess for stenosis & Allows for simultaneous intervention.
    • Invasive, expensive, and risk of atheroembolism and contrast toxicity.
  • Captopril Renography with Technetium-99m (99mTc MAG3): (Option A)
    • Evaluates renal function and perfusion changes after captopril administration.
    • Enhances the detection of differences in renal perfusion due to induced changes in filtration pressure; a normal study can exclude renovascular hypertension.
    • Less reliable in patients with advanced atherosclerosis or serum creatinine levels >2.0 mg/dL (177 μmol/L).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with resistant hypertension, and imaging studies reveal findings in the renal arteries, as shown in the image. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
In young women with resistant hypertension and imaging findings suggestive of fibromuscular dysplasia (beading of the renal arteries), percutaneous renal artery angioplasty is typically the most appropriate management option.

Management of Renal Artery Stenosis:

  • First-Line Treatment: Medical therapy (Antihypertensive medications)
    • ACE-i + CCB + α-Blocker (Option A)
    • Blockade of the RAAS, achieving target BP levels & cessation of tobacco use
    • Statins & Aspirin (Option C) are added for patients with atherosclerotic disease.
    • Atherosclerotic Renal Artery Stenosis (ARAS): If blood pressure can be controlled and kidney function remains stable, medical therapy with follow-up may be as effective as revascularisation over 3–5 years.
  • Interventional Therapy: Renal revascularisation is generally reserved for patients failing medical therapy or developing complications.
    • Consider Interventional procedures in:
      • Young patients (under 40) are suspected of renal artery stenosis.
      • Resistant hypertension despite multiple antihypertensive agents.
      • Individuals with a history of "flash" pulmonary oedema.
      • Those experiencing accelerated or malignant hypertension.
      • Patients whose renal function is worsening.
    • Percutaneous Renal Artery Angioplasty: Particularly effective in cases of non-atheromatous fibromuscular dysplasia, where it can significantly improve blood pressure and renal function.

Renal Artery Angioplasty" data-author="" data-hash="8439" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="" height="546" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/W1sdLyCLtZpkGJJBsW5o1744280800.png" width="546" />

  • Complications: Occur in less than 5% of cases
    • Renal artery dissection
    • Capsular perforation
    • Hemorrhage
    • Atheroembolic disease (rare but can be catastrophic)
  • Outcomes:
    • Renal function recovery occurs in approximately 25% of cases, with no change in 50% and deterioration in others.
    • Patients with rapid loss of kidney function or extensive vascular disease affecting functional kidney mass are more likely to recover.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with hypertension that remains uncontrolled despite being treated with a combination of a calcium channel blocker (CCB) and an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB). What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
When hypertension remains uncontrolled with a Calcium channel blocker (CCB) and an Angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB), adding a thiazide diuretic such as Hydrochlorothiazide is often recommended.

 

Stepwise Management of Hypertension:

Hypertension " data-author="" data-hash="8441" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="" height="682" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/NOzGIgO3MvgN9Jzhvp611744280903.png" width="608" />

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with severe hypertension (BP 220/140 mmHg), headache, and altered mental status. Fundoscopy shows retinal haemorrhages, and laboratory tests indicate elevated serum creatinine. What histopathological finding is most likely seen in the kidney of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario with severe hypertension along with features of encephalopathy and declining renal function along with retinal haemorrhages points towards Malignant hypertension.
  • Fibrinoid necrosis is characteristic of malignant hypertension, indicating severe damage to the vascular structures.

 

Malignant Hypertension: (Arteriolonephrosclerosis)

  • It is characterized by the rapidly progressive increase in blood pressure (BP) leading to target organ damage, including:
    • Retinal haemorrhages
    • Encephalopathy
    • Declining kidney function - rising creatinine and occasionally hematuria and proteinuria
  • Cause: Activation of the RAAS and severe vasospasm due to catecholamine release. Endothelial injury can also provoke microangiopathic hemolysis.
  • Mortality rates exceed 50% within 6 to 12 months in untreated cases.
  • Histopathology:
    • Fibrinoid necrosis involves the breakdown of vessel walls, accumulation of eosinophilic material (including fibrin), and a surrounding infiltration of cells.
    • Onionskin lesions: These lesions, seen in larger interlobular arteries, exhibit hyperplastic proliferation of vascular wall cells, collagen deposition, and separation of vessel layers.
  • These pathological changes can lead to obliteration of glomeruli and tubular structures, resulting in progressive kidney failure, often requiring dialysis for survival.
  • Biochemical Findings: Evidence of hemolysis (anaemia, schistocytes, and reticulocytosis)
  • Management: The primary treatment is aggressive Antihypertensive therapy.
    • Current survival rates over five years exceed 50% with proper management.

 

Hyaline arteriolosclerosis (Option B) is commonly associated with chronic hypertension; it is not the primary finding in malignant hypertension.

 

Diffuse glomerulosclerosis (Option C) typically occurs in chronic kidney diseases and is characterised by scarring in the glomeruli. While it can be seen in patients with longstanding hypertension, it is not specific to the acute changes associated with malignant hypertension.


Tubulointerstitial fibrosis (Option D) refers to scarring of the kidney interstitium and tubules, often seen in chronic kidney diseases. It does not represent the acute vascular changes seen in malignant hypertension, where fibrinoid necrosis is the hallmark finding.
